occurrences.line_text: They backe returned to the Princely Place;
Vp-rose Duessa from her resting place,
In haste Duessa from her place arose,
But comes vnto the place, where th'Hethen knight
That dreaded Night in brightest day hath place,
It carried, that I scarse in darkesome place
Vnto the place, whereas the Paynim lay,
With smoake and sulphure hiding all the place,
They all beholding worldly wights in place,
Vnto the place they come incontinent:
The wyld woodgods arriued in the place,
And soone he came, as he the place had ghest,
And eke this battels end, will need another place.
Vpbrayd, for leauing her in place vnmeet,
Be such as she her selfe was then in place.
From top to toe no place appeared bare,
This was the auncient keeper of that place,
When I awoke, and found her place deuoyd,
And washed all her place with watry eyen.
Next to that Ladies loue, shalbe the place,
Me reft from it, had bene partaker of the place.
By you, when ye arriue in that same place;
Arise, Sir knight arise, and leaue this cursed place.
That aged Dame, the Ladie of the place:
Here in this place, or any other wight,
Loe two most goodly virgins came in place,
Downe in a darkesome lowly place farre in,
The second was as Almner of the place,
And shortly backe returne vnto this place,
And many bloudie battailes fought in place
And to the place, where all our perils dwell;
And found no place his deadly point to rest.
Vp rose the gentle virgin from her place,
All were she dayly with himselfe in place,
By certaine signes here set in sundry place
That from his head no place appeared to his feete.
Would God thy selfe now present were in place,
Which to auenge, he to this place me led,
And thenceforth were renowmd, & sought from place to place.
And thenceforth were renowmd, & sought from place to place.
And turning to that place, in which whyleare
How in that place straunge knight arriued late,
But ere they could proceede vnto the place,
Sith last I left that honorable place,
Still cald vpon to kill him in the place.
Eftsoones he came vnto th'appointed place,
Abandon this forestalled place at erst,
Varlet, this place most dew to me I deeme,
And now is come to that same place, where first she weft.
Your yron brestes, or pittie could find place,
Of euery place, that was with brusing harmd,
What secret place (quoth he) can safely hold
And found no place, where safe he shroud him might,
Ne euer could within one place be found,
Another blis before mine eyes I place,
More fit amongst blacke fiendes, then men to haue his place.
The Palmer seeing his left empty place,
And left his headlesse body bleeding all the place.
Suffise, that I haue done my dew in place.
Behold, who list, both one and other in this place.
Nine was the circle set in heauens place,
Soone as the gracious Alma came in place,
Next Memprise, as vnworthy of that place,
For Aruirage his brothers place supplide,
Whose emptie place the mightie Oberon
besiege her dwelling place:
And round about in fittest steades did place,
In strong entrenchments he did closely place,
The noble virgin, Ladie of the place,
That groueling to the ground he fell, and fild his place.
A daungerous and detestable place,
A place pickt out by choice of best aliue,
They in that place him Genius did call:
Of that sweet place, yet suffred no delight
The art, which all that wrought, appeared in no place.
Some goodly swayne of honorable place,
And of the fairest late, now made the fowlest place.
To weet if they would turne backe to that place:
Ne byte before, but rome from place to place,
Ne byte before, but rome from place to place,
Mote Princes place beseeme so deckt to bee.
To trauell, goe to see that dreadfull place:
Was neuer so great wast in any place,
He liu'd, returning to his natiue place,
And comming to the place, where all in gore
Out of her fleshly ferme fled to the place of paine.
As did Belphoebe, in the bloudy place,
Beside the same a dainty place there lay,
Thou a meane Squire, of meeke and lowly place,
Whence he it fetcht out of her natiue place,
The higher place in her Heroick mind:
Faire Amoretta in the second place:
Through all the woods, to search from place to place,
Through all the woods, to search from place to place,
So faire a place, as Nature can deuize:
Vnto the place, to which her hope did guyde,
She grew familiare in that desert place.
Till her he had attaind, and brought in place,
But ere the stroke could seize his aymed place,
And seeing none in place, he gan to make
Either for want of handsome time and place,
Gan causen, why she could not come in place;
But none of those excuses could take place;
When so in open place, and commune bord,
Nought wants but time and place, which shortly shee
Ne wist he how to turne, nor to what place;
Ne stayd he, till he came vnto the place,
Assayld the flame, the which eftsoones gaue place,
The goodly ordinance of this rich place,
And solemne silence ouer all that place:
His rolling eyes did neuer rest in place,
Soone as that virgin knight he saw in place,
At last she came vnto the place, where late
The custome of that place was such, that hee
All manie nights, and manie by in place,
That fayrest Florimell was present there in place.
But she as Fayes are wont, in priuie place
He lightly lept out of his place of rest,
To Ladies loue, where so he came in place,
Vnto the place of turneyment they came;
Appear'd in place, with all his noble crew:
So fitly now here commeth next in place,
Appear'd in place, the which each other did outgoe.
Assembled in one place: ne he that thought
Yet not fit place he thought it there to stay,
Her list no longer in that place abide;
Oft chaunging sides, and oft new place electing,
So euery place seem'd painefull, and ech changing vaine.
Long time resist, gaue place to kindly rest,
Vnto some resting place, which mote befall,
And in a priuy place, betwixt vs hight,
For in that place where I him thought to find,
And that same gentle Squire arriu'd in place,
The place there ouerflowne, seemd like a sodaine flood.
Thence she them brought toward the place, where late
And finding there fit solitary place
In th'end she her vnto that place did guide,
Well weend, that he had beene some man of place,
It would haue cleft him to the girding place,
So twixt themselues they pointed time and place,
Hauing a keeper still with him in place;
A sunder, yet not euer in one place,
By fortune in that place did chance to light:
And purchase me some place amongst the best.
And to the place of perill shortly came.
That was to weet the Porter of the place,
The onely pleasant and delightfull place,
That in this ioyous place they mote haue ioyance free.
Vnto that purposd place I did me draw,
Doest fayrest shine, and most adorne thy place,
That same was fayrest Amoret in place,
They saw it all, and present were in place;
To view the building of that vncouth place,
There did she pause, inforced to giue place,
When he in place his dearest loue did spy;
Which to another place I leaue to be perfected.
Foure times his place he shifted hath in sight,
Where she hath now an euerlasting place,
In that same place, whereas it now doth lie.
When to the place they came, where Artegall
And place deserued with the Gods on hy.
Vnto the place he came within a while,
For whatsoeuer from one place doth fall,
The time and place was blazed farre and wide;
Now when as Artegall arriu'd in place,
And with faire words, fit for the time and place,
In euery place, and euery place thought best,
In euery place, and euery place thought best,
Yet found no place, that could her liking please,
Ne would she stay, till he in place could come,
By change of place seeking to ease her paine;
That gaue none other place. Which when as hee
But kept her place with courage confident,
And heauenly honours in the highest place;
Then hoping that the change of aire and place
Who bringing them to their appointed place,
Durst not endure their sight, but fled from place to place.
Durst not endure their sight, but fled from place to place.
Flying from place to place with cowheard shame,
Flying from place to place with cowheard shame,
They both resoluing now to leaue the place,
And eke the fastnesse of his dwelling place,
To vnderstand that villeins dwelling place,
I would you guyde directly to the place.
Both ouer rockes, and hilles, and euery place,
Nigh to the place, which ye desir'd to see:
When these two stranger knights arriu'd in place,
A Ladie of great countenance and place,
And new accusements to produce in place:
And meriteth to haue as high a place,
Vnto some place, where they mote rest and feede,
Some place shall vs receiue, and harbour yield;
The Ladie counseld him the place to shonne,
And leueld all against one certaine place,
His groning soule vnto her place of punishment.
And prayd the place of her abode to learne.
Was stretched forth, that nigh fild all the place,
Till nigh vnto the place at length approcht he has.
And time and place conuenient to areed,
But comming to the place, and finding there
The which in all mens liking gayned place,
Yet know I not or how, or in what place
And thee captyued in this shamefull place?
Ere he doe come, he should be soone in place.
But ere he came in place, that youth had kild
Vnto the place, where me he left behind:
But wayt on him in euery place and part.
Came to the place, whereas ye heard afore
How thence she might conuay him to some place.
Let none therefore, that is in meaner place,
And pleasaunce of the place, the which was dight
Forst to forgoe his pray there in the place,
Came to the place, where he his Lady found
Till to some place of rest they mote attaine,
He chaunst to spie a faire and stately place,
An armed Knight approaching to the place,
Who to him aunswer'd, that there was no place
By this the other came in place likewise,
Yet he him still pursew'd from place to place,
Yet he him still pursew'd from place to place,
With speede vnto the place, whereas he last
To bring him to the place, where he would faine,
Some place of succour to content his mynd,
A stranger wight in place, her plaint she stayd,
Be lacke of children, to supply your place,
Agreeing well both with the place and season,
She saw now left, she cast to leaue the place,
He gan to shrinke, and somewhat to giue place,
To seeke some place, the which mote yeeld some ease
Whom when the Hermite present saw in place,
And from the earth, appointed haue her place,
Which when the Saluage comming now in place,
He fled from roome to roome, from place to place,
He fled from roome to roome, from place to place,
Vntill fit time and place he mote espy,
Backe to the place, where Turpine late he lore;
And needs with him streight to the place would ryde,
How both he and his fellow there in place
Backe to the place, whereas his Lord he sleeping vew'd.
And lifted vp to honorable place,
Through her dispiteous pride, whilest loue lackt place,
The witnesse of his wretchednesse, in place,
Whether to slay her there vpon the place,
So round about her they them selues did place
From pitch of higher place, vnto this low degree.
Tooke Coridon, and set him in his place,
Shall more conueniently in other place be ended.
Vnto a place, whose pleasaunce did appere
Vnto this place, and therein to repose
Vnto this place when as the Elfin Knight
Thy Loue is present there with thee in place,
For being gone, none can them bring in place,
Haue for more honor brought her to this place,
But quite are dimmed, when she is in place.
And vnderneath thy feete to place her prayse;
And also of the place, whose pleasures rare
Into this place was brought, and kept with gard
Arriu'd in place, their bondslaues for to buy;
Vnto the place, to see what should be donne.
Tho to the place when they approched nye,
That all the place with swarmes do ouerlay,
That to his loue sometimes he came in place,
Bedeaw'd with teares there left it in the place:
Came to the place, where when he wrapped found
Through euery place, with restlesse paine and toile
Who now no place besides vnsought had left,
Him in a narrow place he ouertooke,
And placed vnder stately canapee,
Duessa placed is, and on a tree
On euery side they placed were along.
Therein two gates were placed seemly well:
There placed was a caudron wide and tall,
And lo shee shall be placed here in sight,
Vnder a steepe hilles side it placed was,
And in the midst thereof a piller placed;
And her against sweet Cherefulnesse was placed,
Amongst them all she placed him most low,
On either part, she placed th'one on th'one,
There eke he placed a strong garrisone,
Vnto a strangers loue so lightly placed,
For whether they be placed high aboue,
Vpon a litle hillocke she was placed
And in the middest of those same three, was placed
Being now placed in the firmament,
That in the midst was placed parauaunt,
For be the fourth with those three other placed:
And prises to them placed at their pleasure,
Through her thin weed their places only signifide.
All other pleasant places doth excell,
Out of their proper places farre away,
Are not all places full of forraine powres?
Corflambo chaseth Placidas,
In steed of whom forth came I Placidas,
Her captiue louers friend, young Placidas:
And Placidas, they both vnto him ran,
The heauy plague, that for such leachours is prepard.
The shame of men, and plague of womankind,
To be the plague and scourge of wretched men:
That plagues, and mischiefs, and long misery
And them with plagues and murrins pestilent
There whereas all the plagues and harmes abound,
That glauncing fire out of the yron plaid;
Or cursed hand hath plaid this cruell part,
Some plaid with strawes, some idly sat at ease;
And in the midst a little riuer plaide
And of his lucklesse lot and cruell loue thus plaind.
A Gentle Knight was pricking on the plaine,
By which he saw the vgly monster plaine,
Where plaine none might her see, nor she see any plaine.
Where plaine none might her see, nor she see any plaine.
And ouerflow each plaine and lowly dale:
That path he kept, which beaten was most plaine,
But euery hill and dale, each wood and plaine
Whose borrowed beautie now appeareth plaine
He leaues the welkin way most beaten plaine,
And all prostrate vpon the lowly plaine,
Plaine, faithfull, true, and enimy of shame,
That they the woods are past, & come now to the plaine.
Then wonne from death, she bad him tellen plaine
As great a noyse, as when in Cymbrian plaine
He shew'd him painted in a table plaine,
Both plaine, and pleasant to be walked in,
Long he them bore aboue the subiect plaine,
And ouerflowed all the fertill plaine,
Yet was their manner then but bare and plaine:
Whom if ye please for to discouer plaine,
But vnder simple shew and semblant plaine
To plaine of wrongs, which had committed bin
But easie is the way, and passage plaine
Demaunded, I made plaine and euident,
Ere on the plaine fast pricking Guyon spide
And laid him downe vpon a grassie plaine;
That stretcht it selfe into an ample plaine,
The want thereof now greatly gan to plaine,
With suddein fury all the fertile plaine,
But soone as him dismounted on the plaine,
That it rebounds against the lowly plaine,
It plaine, and by the sea discoloured:
A large and spacious plaine, on euery side
So through the Christall waues appeared plaine:
Cannot your glorious pourtraict figure plaine
At last as through an open plaine they yode,
On equall plaine, and there so hard beset;
But faire before the gate a spatious plaine,
Ah (said she then) now may ye all see plaine,
That plaine discouered her incontinence,
Did vse to hide, and plaine apparaunce shonne:)
To her reuealed in a mirrhour plaine,
And yet was loth to let her purpose plaine appeare.
Both slaine in battell vpon Layburne plaine,
Whose future woes so plaine he fashioned,
Great Vlfin thrise vpon the bloudy plaine,
Of Greekish bloud so oft in Troian plaine;
With heauie looke and lumpish pace, that plaine
The soueraigne weede betwixt two marbles plaine
Spreading it selfe into a spatious plaine.
Emongst the pumy stones, which seemd to plaine
As was his wont in forrest, and in plaine;
And largely ouerflow the fruitfull plaine,
They spyde a knight faire pricking on the plaine,
This crafty Paramoure, and now it plaine displayd.
One day, as he forpassed by the plaine
Vpon the plaine, the which himselfe prepar'd
And therefore prayd her wake, to heare him plaine.
What boots it plaine, that cannot be redrest,
What boots it then to plaine, that cannot be redrest?
But that such as she was, she plaine did shew;
As plaine as at the first, when they were fresh and greene.
Whom when as Paridel more plaine beheld,
Which when she saw, downe on the bloudy plaine
That both rebutted, tumble on the plaine:
Out of the field, that none perceiu'd it plaine.
Full many deedes that day were shewed plaine:
But shortly was likewise seene lying on the plaine.
Who[m] when they nigh approcht, they plaine descryde
And drawing nigh, when as he plaine descride
Right plaine appeard, though she it would dissemble,
What mister wight it was that so did plaine?
Of all the accident, there hapned plaine,
Shall in this storie find approued plaine;
Before that Castle was an open plaine,
And left them groning there vpon the plaine.
So went he playing on the watery plaine.
Vnder the which, her feet appeared plaine,
Daughter me seemes of double wrong ye plaine,
And for what cause; the truth discouer plaine.
They all are wandred much; that plaine appeares.
But yet he pricked ouer yonder plaine,
But Artegall by signes perceiuing plaine,
In the wide champian of the Ocean plaine:
Like as the sea (which plaine he shewed there)
And make them leuell with the lowly plaine:
So did he, and then plaine it did appeare,
Thereby Sir Artegall did plaine areed,
That shattered all to peeces round about the plaine.
And to her mercie him submitted in plaine field.
Well weend she then, ere him she plaine descride,
A Knight, that softly paced on the plaine,
Was Artegall, by many tokens plaine;
By thundring Ioue in the Phlegrean plaine.
And her proud person low prostrated on the plaine.
As they vpon him prest, it plaine to them did shew.
Then Artegall himselfe dicouering plaine,
Though plaine she saw by all, that she did heare,
They both encounter in the middle plaine,
That all the three attonce fell on the plaine:
That foot of man might sound the bottome plaine,
There to be pitched on the open plaine;
Like as a tender Rose in open plaine,
Whom when he saw prostrated on the plaine,
Yet being matcht with plaine Antiquitie,
He him pursu'd and chaced through the plaine,
They bene ymett in middest of the plaine,
By thee no knight; which armes impugneth plaine?
Together with this Ladie, passing on the plaine.
As by his manners, in which plaine is showne
And by good fortune the plaine champion wonne:
Therefore conspiring all together plaine,
Till towards night they came vnto a plaine,
But with entire affection and appearaunce plaine.
But all her hinder parts did plaine expresse
Plaine signes in him of life and liuelihead.
Did laugh at those that did lament and plaine:
She from her palfrey lighted on the plaine,
I gan my follies to my selfe to plaine,
It was an hill plaste in an open plaine,
And on the top thereof a spacious plaine
Or false dissemblaunce all them plaine may see,
That through his carkasse one might plainely see:
Whose face discouered, plainely did expresse
The signes of anguish one mote plainely read,
Bewrayd it selfe, to let men plainely wot,
The sea it selfe doest thou not plainely see
And let that losell, plainely now displayd,
(An vncouth sight) he plainely then descride
So now Malfont was plainely to be red;
By certaine signes he plainely him descryde,
That plainely may in this wyld man be red,
But when the Prince had once him plainely eyde,
But plainely gan to him declare the case
But when approching neare, he plainely found,
In which that rose she plainely saw displayd.
In plainer wise to tell her grieuaunce she begonne.
Hath thus transformd, and plast in open plaines,
Through woods and plaines so long I did her chace,
The fruitfull plaines, and with fell cruelty,
Through hils, through dales, throgh forests, & throgh plaines
He sought the plaines; but could no tydings heare.
That doth this Redcrosse knights ensample plainly proue.
And the faire land it selfe did plainly show.
Then of them all she plainly was espyde,
Through thick and thin, through mountaines & through plains,
That doth his course through Blandford plains direct,
Through thick and thin, through mountains & through plains,
In secret anguish and vnpittied plaint,
Redounding teares did choke th'end of her plaint,
Haue vowd you to defend. Now then your plaint appease.
Certes, Madame, ye haue great cause of plaint,
And bad tell on the tenor of his plaint;
The knight was greatly moued at his plaint,
The varlet at his plaint was grieu'd so sore,
Pitty our plaint, and yield vs meet reliefe.
She shut vp all her plaint in priuy griefe;
Of her vaine plaint, and to her scoffing sayd;
With womanish compassion of her plaint,
And gan to her her mournfull plaint to make,
Let then this plaint vnto his eares be borne,
There she began to make her monefull plaint
A stranger wight in place, her plaint she stayd,
And shut vp all his plaint in priuy paine.
That all her piteous plaint they did refuse,
Her mournefull plaintes, beguiled of her art,
At last forth breaking into bitter plaintes
Choking the remnant of his plaintife speach,
To heare the piteous beast pleading her plaintiffe cause.
And ruefull plaints, me bidding guiltlesse bloud to spare?
And piteous plaints she filleth his dull eares,
And with loud plaints importuneth the skyes,
These piteous plaints and dolours did resound;
That through the sea the resounding plaints did fly:
With sighes, and sobs, and plaints, & piteous griefe,
Where also many plaints to her were brought,
But all in vaine, her plaints might not preuaile,
Will yeeld, but when my piteous plaints he heares,
In waylfull plaints, that none was to appease;
But more enforst my paine, the more my plaints to heare.
And all the woods with piteous plaints did fill,
Tho when as all her plaints she had displayd,
Whiles dayly plaisters to his wound she layd,
Which feedes each liuing plant with liquid sap,
And their bright Squadrons round about vs plant,
In Paradize whilome did plant this flowre,
To plant or prune: for of their owne accord
Another plant, that raught to wondrous hight,
That was an oaken plant, which lately hee
Great God it planted in that blessed sted
And planted there, did bring forth fruit of gold:
And planted there their huge artillery,
Planted with mirtle trees and laurels greene,
They in that Gardin planted be againe;
